objinfo.printdate: 1795The characteristics of the color printing indicate that this impression is the second one printed in 1795. The hand coloring may have been touched up by Blake shortly before he delivered the print to Thomas Butts in 1805. The first impression in this printing is *Lamech and His Two Wives* in the collection of Robert N. Essick (Butlin 298).
objinfo.objsize: 43.1 x 60.8 cm.The printing of the corners indicates that the unusual octagonal format was created by the printing matrix, not by subsequent trimming of the printed leaf of paper. See also *Naomi Entreating Ruth and Orpah to Return to the Land of Moab* in the Victoria and Albert Museum (Butlin 299) for the same format.
objinfo.medium: planographic color printing with water color and pen and ink additions to the impression

provenance.note: Acquired by Thomas Butts in 1805 from Blake; Thomas Butts, Jr., apparently by inheritance in 1845; Frederick J. Butts, apparently by inheritance in 1862; offered at Sotheby's, 24 June 1903, lot 1 (apparently bought-in at £156 by the dealer Stephens and returned to F. J. Butts); the widow of F. J. Butts by inheritance in 1905; sold 1906 through Carfax and Co., London, to W. Graham Robertson; given 1939 by Robertson to the Tate Gallery (now Tate Collection).

desc.objtitle: Lamech and His Two Wives (Tate Collection), Object 1 (Butlin 297)

objnote.p: The subject of "Lamech and His Two Wives" is derived from Genesis 4:23-4. Lamech, a descendent of Cain and the central figure in the design, has in a rage killed the young man lower right. Lamech clutches his head in despair and in the knowledge that the penalty of Cain will fall on him "seventy and sevenfold" (Genesis 4:24). Lamech's two wives, Adah and Zillah, cling together on the left. Blake may have known the more detailed telling of the story in the Apocrypha, as well as the traditional association between Lamech's son, Tubalcain, and metal working.
The title, "Lamech and his two Wives," is inscribed in pencil below the design, almost certainly not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The central figure, Lamech, holds his head in distress as he stares at the dead body lying on the ground to the right. His two wives, Adah and Zillah, stand to the left of Lamech, embracing each other as they look toward their husband. A flowing piece of drapery, perhaps part of a tent, descends along the left margin of the design. The background is mountainous and dark, with a dark cloud upper right. The ground is covered in low vegetation (grass, moss, or lichens?).

component.illusobjdesc: Lamech, the central figure, pulls at his hair with clenched hands. His upper arms are extended horizontally from his body, with elbows bent and his lower arms reaching upward to his head. He stares to the right at the dead body on the ground with a facial expression of despair and agony. He has short (?) hair and a long beard. His left foot is prominent at the hem of his flowing gown. As he faces the viewer, he stands with his torso twisting slightly to the right.

Adah and Zillah, Lamech's two wives, embrace each other as they stand to the left of Lamech. The woman on the left has long, flowing curly hair. She appears to be gowned from the hips to the feet. Her right arm is under the other woman’s left arm and wrapped around the second woman’s waist. Her left arm must be similarly wrapped around the other side of the woman’s torso, for her left hand rests along the other woman's side just below the right hand. It seems that her left hand is clutching the gown. She faces forward but twists to the right; one knee (the right?) is prominent. Her mouth is slightly opened and she stares at the scene unfolding before her with eyes raised and a facial expression of fear.

Adah and Zillah, Lamech's two wives, embrace each other as they stand to the left of Lamech. The woman on the right has long, flowing hair. She appears to be gowned from the hips to her feet. Her right arm is not pictured, but her left arm is over the other woman’s right arm, embracing her hip. Her left hand may be clutching the gown. We see her from behind, but her face is twisted to right profile. Her right leg is slightly behind her left leg as if in stride towards the other woman’s arms. Her right foot is on tiptoe, and is prominent at the hem of her gown. Her neck is severely twisted to the right to stare at the scene unfolding before her.

Lower right is a muscular dead male lying prone on the ground. His arms are sprawled outward parallel to the ground in a cruciform position. His left arm seems slightly bent at the elbow, although the forearm is not pictured. His right hand, palm down, is prominently pictured left of Lamech's lower legs. The dead man appears to be nude with short, curly hair.
Along the left margin of the design there appears to be a piece of flowing drapery that may be the side of a tent.
The mounds in the foreground of the design are covered in grass, moss, lichens, or some such vegetation.
Dark mountains rise in the background. Above the mountains upper right is a dark, stormy cloud that blackens the surrounding sky.
